abstract: A fundamental component responsible for low bit error rate (BER) is the phase jitter of the frequency reference source, regardless if a network is wireless or fiber optic in nature.  In the case of wireless the frequency reference source is typically a voltage controlled oscillator (VCO), and in the fiber optic case it is a clock.  In order to maximize the full benefit of spread spectrum techniques, such as code division multiple access (CDMS), frequency hopping in secure communications, or allowing a high number of users to occupy the same frequency band , the BER must be kept to an acceptable level.  Phase I work will primarily concentrate on devloping and measuring prototype reference sources that can satisfy the phase jitter and phase noise requirements required by high speed digital wireless and fiber optic systems.  When defining a reference source, digital designers tend to specify phase jitter while RF engineers use phase noise.  Although phase jitter and phase noise are related, they are not interchangeable in a casual sense.  Therefore, part of Phse I will also be devoted to defining relationships between these parameters, allowing the reference sources developed to be characterized in a meaningful way.  Anticipated Military Benefits/Potential Commercial Applications of the Research or Development:  This effort will result in significantly better understanding of frequency reference sources capable of meeting phase noise and phase jitter performance requirements in dual use high digital data rate applications.  Prototype sources investigated in Phase I will result in commercially available sources in Phase II.
title: Improved Reference Sources for Low-Bit Error Rate Communication In Digital Wireless and Fiber Optic Systems

abstract: Refractory Composites, Inc. has developed an organometallic chemical vapor deposition process for an oxidation resistant long life precious metal coating suitable for rocket engine application and a number of related hot long life aerospace applications. The proposed Phase I program seeks to exploit this technology through a scale-up phase and test article thermal cycling and oxidation testing phase. A planned Phase II program would result in performance demonstrated rocket engine results.  This new coating technology is expected to reduce the cost of thick precious metal coatings by a factor of five, while improving the reliability of the coating process over the current CVD coating technique.
title: Low Cost Precious Metal Rocket Engine Coatings
REGENERATIVELY COOLED C/SIC ROCKET COMBUSTORS

title: NEW NEBULIZER FOR IMPROVED AEROSOL DELIVERY

abstract: A  group of at least 30 volunteers will be repeatedly screened for their ability to attract Aedes agypti mosquitoes.  Individuals who are consistently least attractive and consistently most attractive to mosquitoes will be identified.  Techniques and chemical traps will be revaporiezed in an olfactometer to verify relative attractancy.  A second portion of the trapped emanations will be used to develop methods for gas chromatography-mass spectroscopic analysis.  These techniques will ultimately be used in PHase II to identiy chemical components which differ significanly betweeen the least attractive and most attractive subjects.
title: Development of an Insect Repellent Based on human Skin Emanations

abstract: To meet dependability requirements dictated by current trends in both defense and commercial technologies, massive modular redundancy and application specific designs will have to give way to more efficient, scalable and cost-effective approaches.  This Phase I proposal introduces a method which takes a basic architectural approach to fault-tolerant system design.  The proposed research will address techniques which improve the reliability of large, heterogeneous, distributed systems consisting of both fixed and mobile computing nodes.  This approach will offer a hierarchical recovery scheme which begins recovery at the chip/board level and ranges through the node and network levels.  Proposed research will allow a range of systems to be designed and built using commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) technology; system design and implementation will be kept cost-effective, while also allowing versatility of design.
title: Hierarchical Design Methodologies for High Availability Systems

abstract: The thrust of the proposed research is to develop a comprehensive   and cost effective automated test insertion tool for boards and   systems designed using Commercial Off-The Shelf (COTS) devices.   The research will investigate promising test methodologies for   testing non BIST devices in the board and design a tool that can   analyze and propose design changes to enhance testability in a   commercial board design framework.  This will make it possible for   the COTS to be used extensively in military system designs without   compromising the testability of the system.  Phase I research will   focus on procedures for board test architecture evalautions, test   pattern generation in self test framework, test response   compactions, test session scheduling schemes and formulation of   metrics to evaluate various overheads that result from testability   enhancement changes.  During this phase, we also plan to initiate   the design of a prototype tool.  This prototype tool will be tested   on benchmark designs and industrial examples that will be made   available to use from Mentor Graphics and AT&T.  If the objectives   are satisfied, we propose to implement the techniques selected   through the Phase I research and develop an efficient test   insertion tool for possible commercialization.
title: CAD Tool for Design for Testability Using Commercial Off-the-Shelf Components

abstract: Extensive research (Ukraine) has shown that high strength continuous fibers of basalt can be produced.  These fibers are inexpensive and have exceptionally high strength, stiffness and corrosion resistance.  Basalt is a naturally occurring volcanic mineral, consisting a variety concentration of oxides.  The product envisioned is a low-cost, corrosion resistant replacement for steel bar in reinforced concrete.  It is proposed to develop a higher strength non-corrosive basalt fiber base composite ultimate to steel.  The innovation of this project is cost effective technology to manufacture continuous basalt fibers (0.0001 to 0.0002 inch in diameter) in amorphous state without crystalline phase which by Mechanical Performance/Price Ratios better than S-1, S-2 glass fibers.  The polymer bonded continuous basalt fiber composite appear to have roughly twice the stiffness and strength of E-glass composites, and about one half that of high performance carbon fibers.  It is expected that Phase I of project will determine the feasibility of using basalt fiber composites to reinforce structural concrete.  This material will be evaluated to determine properties and to study its compatibility with typical road building concrete.  Phase II project would involve building a pilot plant to produce and test composite bars made of Wisconsin basalt.
title: Advanced Concept Basalt Fiber Reinforcement for Concrete

abstract: The overall goal is to develop a marketable product in the form of a computer based methodology will be developed and validated in Phase I.  The development will require innovative R&D to formulate a pragmatic mechanism-based (mechanistic) modeling framework which will later form the basis for a more comprehensive methodology. The present proposal is to develop and assess the feasibility of an innovative, fundametally sound, and pragmatic mechanistic approach which RAI has formulated.  An important part of our approach involves destructive as well as non-destructive elavuation (NDE) of OTPC test samples to identify and quanify damage.  To ensure that effort leads to a product which is directly useful (and, therefore, marketable) RAI proposes to work in close collaboration will Allied Signal Aerospace in addressing their immediate interest in OTPC technology relevant to an IHPTET impeller design.  However, the proposed product will be immediately and directly marketable to commercial aerospace and automotive industries, and to stationary gas turbine engine and large engine manufactureres.
title: Design Tool for Oxidation and Thermal Protection Coatings

abstract: The overall goal of the proposed effort is to develop and market a high technology, dual-use product in the form of a system to implement advanced Damage Tolerant Design technology in both military and commercial applications involving the use of high temperature polymeric matrix composites (PMCs).  The product will directly and immediately benefit the IHPTET program.  The development of the system will involve non-destructive evaluation (NDE), limited laboratory testing, mechanics modeling, and system integration disciplines.  The achievement of the goal will require innovative research and development (R&D) effort to be performed in Phase I.  The IR&D effort will focus on developing and assessing the feasibility of a mechanistic method for determining residual strength and life of PMC engine components under general spectrum loading and service temperature and environmental conditions of interest.  The development of a mechanistic model is a necessary pre-requisite to developing an integrated system needed by test engineers and designers of both military and commercial aircraft engines and structures, and by engineers in several other industries.
title: A Damage Tolerant Design System for Polymeric Matrix Composite Components
LIFE PREDICTION SOFTWARE & METHODOLOGY FOR TITANIUM MATRIX COMPOSITES

abstract: Many simulations environments, particularly those used for training purposes, employ simulated human behavior.  To date, users frequently complain that such simulated behavior is not very intelligent and easy to "game" thus reducing the effectiveness of the training.  We propose to improve intelligent agent technology through improved techniques for eliciting expert problem solving knowledge on what decisions to make in the simulated environment and improved knowledge representation and reasoning techniques that support intelligent evaluations and plannings in response to user actions within a simulation.  Our approach will be demonstrated in a proof-of-concept system that employs intelligent agents in a dismounted infantry fighting environment.  This context will allow us to leverage the proposed work with other projects RDC has, developing simulation-based training for the dismounted infantry.
title: Making Intelligent Agents Intelligent

abstract: Computer Based Training (CBT) systems have been shown to  promote high learning training effectiveness and cost  effectiveness.  To get effective training from these systems,  specific technical knowledge needs capturing.  Unfortunately,  the task of accessing the knowledge stored in the technicians  brains and recording this knowledge has remained difficult  and expensive.  The proposed work would attempt to automate the task of re-  trieving and storing technical data for use by CBT systems.  The "Electronic Capture and Handling, Integrated Engineering  Facts" (e-Chief) system would provide an effective method of  obtaining the knowledge from the individual and using it in  multiple, broad-based CBT applications, in a phased approach.  The e-Chief system would incorporate a cognitive science model  of knowledge elicitation.  The e-Chief system would incorporate  an Instructional Systems Design (ISD) model of training design.  Phase one has two objectives, First, to specify a system  design specification for the processes and tools required to  effectively transmit technical knowledge from a practitioner  to the computer data base.  Second, RDC would perform a  preliminary task analysis on a domain of the clients choosing  to test the data structures required to capture knowledge from  a technical expert.
title: Electronic Capture and Handling, Integrated Engineering Facts (e-Chief)

abstract: Multimedia training technologies are proliferating and offer the opportunity to  provide richer training environments than ever before.  However, these are  expensive to develop.  Little is known about what types of tasks these best  train and how best to invest in them to maximize training objectives.  The  proposed work will develop a methodology for decomposing training tasks  into underlying knowledge components.  Research will then be done to  identify what features of multimedia technologies best train what knowledge  components.  From these data, a trade-off methodology can be developed that  calculates the costs associated with using different multimedia environments  to meet specified training objectives.  Phase I will develop this framework and  trade-off methodology and demonstrate it in a proof-of-concept system for   training tasks and multimedia systems that will be selected in conjunction with  the Navy training community.  Phase II will extend and validate the framework  and trade-off tool.
title: Optimizing Learning Cost-effectively Using Multimedia

abstract: Real-time systems are being called upon to do more complex and inter-related tasks than ever before. Expert systems and other rule-based system are a standard AI technique used to codify human expertise and reasoning capability n a form that a computer can use. However, large systems are typically too slow for many realtime applications. Reticular Systems proposes to solve this problem by developing a VLSI co-processor that will speed up such expert system processing by a factor of 10-1000 times. This increase in speed will open up many new real-time applications that require the intelligence of expert systems. Moreover, the similarity between the low level pattern matching of expert systems and the join process in large relational database searches indicate that this co-processor could be utilized in many database applications where getting the query results in as short a time as possible is critical. Reticular Systems experience in developing intelligent systems (both software and hardware) gives us the unique opportunity to develop and exploit this technology in both commercial and military markets.
title: Pattern Matching Co-Processor for Advanced Reasoning Systems

abstract: The research objective is to develop conceptual designs for intelligent presentations and filtering of Helmet Mounted Display data.  Intelligent information display requires that the system have knowledge about status of unfolding aircraft missions as well as the pilot's intent.  If the system has knowledge of these two items, then it is possible to display appropriate information for a particular mode of flight.  The fundamental challenge is to determine what  information to display, when to display it, where to display the information and how to display it.  Reticular Systems' business focus has been on developing methods for prioritizing and filtering information, presenting appropriate information in a timely manner and preventing information overload. We have identified a number of potential solutions which are based on our development of situation assessment systems for rotorcraft, intelligent operator assistants and intelligent agents for complex reasoning systems and real-time problem solving.  Solutions draw on results for the Air Force Pilot's Associate Program and recent finding in human information processing.  Phase I activities include requirements analysis, technology assessment, deign concepts and prototyping and demonstration of key technologies.  Reticular systems has developed a highly capable Simulation and Test Environment which will be used to evaluate concepts developed.
title: A Contextual Approach to Intelligent Display Management

abstract: Reticular Systems proposes to research and develop a system for the recognition of landmarks and locations from image data, with emphasis on its use as a component in an autonomous navigation system for robotic ground vehicles.  the mthodology proposed is based on a hybrid system consisting of both model-based object recognition techniques and neural network classification of terrain/landmark types.  The information from these two sources is combined by an integration and inferencing component which performs high level reasoning to aid in location recognition and serves as a consistent interface to route planning and position estimation systems.  We will deliver prototype code, simulation results and a final report describing the overall landmark and location recognition system for autonomous navigation of robotic ground vehicles.  The report will detail information requirements, formats, data structures, algorithms, and initial results obtained in the prototype implementation or planned for Phase II. Prototypes and neural netowrk simulators will be used to evaluate the key components of the propsed system and reduce risk for Phase II.  Phase I schedule and scope is realistic and realizable due to our experience in knowledge acquisition, intelligent systems, software development and development of prototyping tools.
title: Using Neural Networks for Battlefield Landmark and Feature Recognition
INTELLIGENT AGENTS AND AGENT COMMUNICATION LANGUAGES FOR OPERATIONS

abstract: Reveo has invented novel thin-film circular polarizer technology that is suitable for harsh space and industrial environments. This technology is based on rotating inorganic birefringent thin films of refractory metal oxides obtained with an innovative variation of conventional vacuum deposition techniques. The polarizers have unprecedented high performance: high operating temperature well above 1000 C, wide operating spectral range from ultraviolet (lOum), an extinction ratio greater than 10,000, non-absorbing, an efficiency near theoretical 50% transmittance or reflectance for unpolarized light and high power handling capability (>l,OOOMW/cm2). The polarizing bandwidth can be engineered by the deposition process. With the same thin film material, polarizers with an extremely broad spectral band from the far infrared to the ultraviolet or with an extremely narrow spectral band (
title: High-Performance Circular Polarizers for Space Applications
Chiral Film Technology for Ultrahigh-Capacity & Ultrafast Retrieval Optical Storage

abstract: In this proposal, we present the design of an Integrated Optics Rotation and Acceleration Sensor (IORAS) that is able to function both as a rotation sensor as well as an accelerometer. The proposed IORAS is based on a rugged integrated optics glass on silicon waveguide distinct advantage of the IORAS over other inertial navigation devices such as silicon forces without saturation and thus can continue to navigate in the gun barrel during the carrier micromachined inertial components is that it has the ability o continue operation under high g launch phase.  It is lightweight, compact, and consumes a minimum of electrical power.  It is potentially much more sensitive than micromachined components, with a wider dynamic range. Its signal processing is trivial in that it requires no crystal oscillator. In addition, an automotive-grade IORAS can be easily mass produced at low cost to meet the performance specifications of a military style inertial navigator.  The outcome of this project will be a set of design specifications for the construction in Phase II of a prototype IORAS capable of inertial navigation of component munitions.
title: Integrated Optics Rotation and Acceleration Sensor (IORAS)
Three Axis Intergrated Optics Rotation Sensor

abstract: Retrieval of atmospheric temperature and water vapor profiles through the use of a novel radiometer design which uses a unique digital signal processing (DSP) software, known as X-MIDAS, and adaptive frequency control to process radiometric measurements of millimeter wave band oxygen and water vapor emissions is proposed.  Temperature and/or water vapor retrieval results are fed back to the radiometer in the form of an updated set of measurement frequencies.  This allows temporal tracking of atmospheric conditions with the potential for increased stability of the retrieval solutions.  Use of DSP techniques to process the radiometer signals improves accuracy, stability and repeatability of the initial radiometric data and permits an increase in the number of discrete frequencies available for measurement, thus improving spatial resolution of the retrieved profiles.
title: DSP Radiometer with Adaptive Frequency Control for the Retrieval of Atmospheric Temperature and Water Vapor Profiles

abstract: Frequency selective surfaces (FSSs) find widespread applications as radomes, dichroic filters and components for satellite antenna systems, and have been extensively investigated in the past.  Much of the attention in these studies has been focused, however, on the in-band performance of versions of these filters and little progress has been reported on the important aspect of RCS reduction, which requires an accurate modeling of the out-of-band scattering characteristics of the FSSs that can be either single or multi-layered, electrically thick, and spaced with dielectric layers whose parameters may vary from layer to layer. In this effort, we propose to carry out the development of computer codes based on the newly developed Genetic Algorithms applied in conjunction with general-purpose and computationally-efficient FSS analysis software developed over the last decade by RM Associates, that would simultaneously optimize the in-band transmission and out-of-band scattering characteristics of multi-layered frequency selective screens. In addition, truncation, curvature, transition and finite-thickness effects would be capability, that would require accurate computation of near fields, would be handled by codes specially adapted for this purpose.
title: High Power Multi-layer Frequency Selective Filters

abstract: In this effort we propose to investigate various techniques for efficient and rapid CAD design of printed circuit antennas and associated circuit components.  While the design of single microstrip patch antenna is relatively well developed, the same can not be said for arrays and antennas mounted on complex structures, especially at high frequencies where the quasi-static models are not accurate and, hence, commercially available tools, e.g. Touchstone cannot be sued for reliable design.  One of the important features of the deign tool will be the ability to extract equivalent circuits from the outputs of field solvers.  These solvers will be rendered efficient by using various techniques that will speed up the required computation.  the availability of equivalent circuits will enable us to employ optimization algorithms in a very efficient manner.  User friendly Graphic User Interface will be an integral part of the tool.  Phase-I will explore the various tools will also develop or refine them on as-needed basis to render them well-adapted for the present task.  Phase-II will integrate these tools to generate the user-friendly ad efficient CAD tool for the design of  printed circuit antennas and associated circuits.
title: Computer-aided Design of Printed Circuit Antennas Using Suite of Optimized Algorithms

abstract: RM Associates (RMA) proposes to develop a novel approach to designing broadband antennas covering the frequency range of 15:1, or even greater, without sacrificing the gain and efficiency of the presently available designs which exhibit a narrower bandwidth. The design methodology will be based upon the newly developed genetic algorithm for solving stochastic optimization problems and is expected to yield greatly superior results than can be achieved by using conventional techniques.  We anticipate that the resultant designs would be useful for high speed, spread spectrum and frequency hopping communication systems because they would be able to meet the requirements that they be low profile, efficient, and offer simultaneous operation over a broad band of frequencies.  Phase I of the effort would involve the development of the genetic algorithm for broadband antenna design; demonstration of the application of the algorithm to a representative antenna of interest to the Navy; assessment of the feasibility of fabrication of the designed antenna; preliminary assessment of the suitability of the design antenna for shipboard environment.  RMA will be assisted in this effort by Parisi Antenna Systems who will consult with RMA and evaluate the feasibility of manufacturing the design antennas.  RMA will also consult with Booz-Allen & Hamilton who are experts in the field of shipboard communication systems.  Completion of the Phase I effort will allow for the development, in Phase II, of a full-scale and fully functional broadband antenna that can be installed and tested within the shipboard environment.
title: INCREASED ANTENNA BANDWIDTH AT HIGH FREQUENCIES WITH FREQUENCY UHF APPLICATIONS

abstract: Laser radar (LADAR) is an emerging technology with the inherent ability to rapidly acquire high resolution range data day or night. Unfortunately current LADAR ranging techniques require an intense, focused beam that is mechanically scanned over a field of view. Mechanical scanning limits the data rate, is weight- and cost-prohibitive for many applications, and can be failure-prone. Scanned range imagery is also susceptible to motion-included distortion, and the high active emissions for scanned LADAR's are undesirable for covert applications and eye safe operation. These systems therefore do not meet the demanding performance requirements of critical military and commercial missions in reconnaissance, surveillance, target acquisition, navigation, and collision avoidance. Robotic Vision Systems, Inc. (RVSI) proposes to conduct a laboratory demonstration to verify the ability of its patented scannerless LADAR technology to acquire "snapshot" images without moving parts, while using eve safe active emissions This demonstration will provide the basis for development of a highly reliable system capable of capturing crisp, high resolution range images under the most demanding high speed, covert operations.
title: Scannerless Imaging Laser Radar
SBIR Phase I: High Speed Sub-Micron Optical 3-D Sensor
ROBOTIC ONLINE LEARNING OF PERCEPTUAL MODELS FOR NAVIGATION AND GRASPING

abstract: Diffractive optics is a promising technology for the aberration correction, athermalization, and achromatization of imaging systems.  Diffractive optical elements (DOEs) can also be used for the generation of fanout arrays, microlens arrays, anti-aliasing gratings, and polarization optics.  Applications include the fabrication of sports and military optics such as light-weight binocular eyepeices and rifle scopes, optical interconnects for communication systems, DOEs for HMDs, and fanout arrays for laser machining.  In order to capitalize upon the advantages diffractive optics has to offer over conventional optics, the technology for manufacturing high-quality, low-cost DOEs needs to be developed.   During Phase I we plan to investigate a novel method of fabrication durable diffractive optics replicas.  Currently, developed replication technologies result in a final diffractive surface that is polymer-based.  For applications involving high temperatures, long-term durability, or applications in the UV spectral region, plastic materials are not suitable.  The replication method we will investigate results in durable DOEs fabricated in substrated materials such as SiO2.  Unlike current fabrication processes whereby each element must be individually pattered via diamond turning or photolithographic techniques, the proposed replication method requires only a single master element to be fabricated in this manner.  Subsequent SiO2 elements are replicated from this master, resulting in lower element cost and in replicas that are durable and suited for multiple dual-use applications in the UV and visible regions of the spectrum.  Anticipated Military Benefits/Potential Commercial Applications of the Research or Development:  Non-plastic DOE replicas have dual-use applications in the UV and visible spectral regions.  Applications include UV lithography, laser machining, lightweight binocular eyepeices, and zoom lenses for camcorders.
title: Low-Cost, High-Volume Replication of Durable Non-PLastic Diffractive Elements for UV and Visible Applications

abstract: The ultimate goal of the proposed program is to commercialize an affordable system that provides combat vehicle personnel with a 360 degree horizontal field of view of the outside world, while providing both ballistic protection and an eye protection against multi-wave and frequency agile lasers. The proposed system surrounds the user with a ring of viewing screens.  Each screen is the output end of a coherent fiber optic imaging taper which is protected by a non-linear optical limiting element. The objective of the Phase I research is to develop a design for a deployable imaging module.  The design will be based upon experimental evaluation of a brassboard prototype module which will subsequently, in Phase II, be used as a test-bed for evaluation of new optical limiting materials,
title: Agile Laser Protection for Combat Vehicle Surveillance Vision Device

abstract:
41089                                           November 20, 1996
Ronin Systems, Inc.

Video compression is a critical technology for maximizing scarce bandwidth.  Different compression techniques offer different advantages, including compression ratio, compression and decompression speed, and image fidelity.  This project will modify and improve an existing compression package. In order to maximize speed, the software will be ported to a message passing massively parallel processor.  The software will also be able to run on networks of workstations to maximize price-performance.  A scalability analysis of the resultant software will be conducted, providing a comprehensive understanding of the different tradeoffs available to prospective users of digital video compression.

Commercial Applications and Other Benefits as described by the awardee:  The software should enable prospective users of digital video to reduce compression time or transmission time, or both, of their signals.  In addition, higher compression ratios will allow users in satellite communications to adopt more robust compression schemes.
title: Wavelet-Based Video Compression for Massively Parallel Processors
WAVELET-BASED IMAGE COMPRESSION FOR SYMMETRIC MULTIPROCESSING

abstract: The results of the proposed Omni-Directional Sensor Mount research and development will be greater usefulness of both old and new Ballistic Missile Defense Organization (BMDO) sensor technology. The innovative design adapts novel patented and patent pending technology, to provide a double-jointed sensor mount which is singularity and gimbal lock-free. The device merges novel patented technology with new patent pending technology to provide a sensor platform that is capable of moving a sensor within a full horizon-to-horizon 180 degree hemispherical range of motion. This requires a mount capable of a full 180 degree horizon-to-horizon movement without incurring the downtime caused by singularities (voids in the range of motion available to the sensor mount). Low weight and zero-backlash enhance positioning speed and accuracy. Ships, amphibious or four-wheel drive vehicles, and other platforms which move in three-dimensional space induce pitch, yaw, and roll motion to the sensor mount. Maintaining sensor lock in rough seas on stationary targets such as geosynchronous satellites, beacons, or other fixed objects is difficult, if not at times impossible, when using current sensor mounts technologies.  Satellite-to-satellite communication in circumstances of tangential or perpendicular orbits requires antenna mounts that can be repositioned in real-time.
title: An Omni-Directional Sensor Mount

abstract: A new high temperature passive damping system is proposed for application to gas turbine engines.  This dry-type damper eliminiates the need for lubricant to provide squeeze film damping.  THE VENAM (tm) damper consists of a high temperature, high stiffness, composite material with vitreous enamel interlayers, which will dissipate vibrational energy viscoelastically.  The effort proposed herein will concentrate on design and fabrication of a prototype damper for a typical gas turbine application and component testing to prove the feasibility of the concept.  Elimination of oil lubricated systems from gas turbine engines.
title: Composite Bearing Damper for Advanced Gas Turbine Engines

abstract: 1. A conceptual baseline design of a hydrogen supply system with a on/off capability will be prepared for delivering hydrogen in increments of up to 10g/hour with a total capacity of 120g hydrogen.  This baseline design will be based upon a solid state hydrogen reactant mixture with a yield of 8% by reactant weight which has been previously qualified for military use.                                                  2.  Solid hydrogen reactant mixtures with theoretical yields of up to 20% will be evaluated and tested for thermal stability, safety, and performance.                                                            3. The baseline hydrogen supply system will be upgraded for incorporation of a higher yielding hydrogen reactant mixture, assuming a suitable replacement is emerging.  The design will demonstrate what yield per system weight is achievable with a solid state hydrogen generating reactant system and provide a concept for phase II development.
agency: Office of the Secretary of Defense
title: Hydrogen Supply System for Small Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) Fuel Cell Stacks

abstract: In a number of IR target-detection systems a small instantaneous field of view (IFOV) of the image sensor is required in order that the target be reliably detected against clutter. A modification (called Spatial Modulation) of the image sensor is proposed by which each IFOV sample or output pixel, is a measure -- not of the average of the scene intensity over the IFOV -- but of the high spatial-frequency content of the scene over the IFOV. In this way the high spatial frequency information needed for target detection in clutter can be obtained with a much larger IFOV, and many fewer pixels, than would otherwise be necessary.
title: Spatial Modulation

abstract: The unique features of microwave power transfer can be harvested for generation of large amounts of electric power thereby eliminating the conventional electric generators needed to operate the systems.  This proposal describes the design concepts that will result in very effective and efficient wireless power transfer (WPT) system.  Using a large number of internally matched FET devices with high power added efficiency (PAE), an active integrated transmitter antenna array generating (DC to RF) a high power microwave beam will be developed.  Such a solid-state transmitter array will also be capable of beam steering in order to keep the beam focused onto a rectenna (mounted to a moving platform) which will be capable of receiving and converting the microwave power into DC power.  Beam steering techniques that will either eliminate the conventional phase shifters or minimize their numbers in the phased arrays will be developed to make the WPT system more efficient and effective.  A rectenna design approaching 100% (RF to DC) conversion efficiency by retrieving the RF power from the higher order harmonics (generated in the rectifier circuits) will be pursued.  Using high power FET devices (PAE exceeding 70%), the WPT systems delivering greater than 60% overall DC to DC conversion efficiency are possible.
title: Alternate Power Sources for Aerostats

abstract: Innovative concepts based on quasi-optial techniques for developing high performance solid-state devices at millimeter-wave frequencies are described.  Using a large number of low power two terminal or three terminal devices, active integrated antenna arrays tha tmeet the requirements of high power solid-state transmitter sources and beam steering capabilities are proposed.  Such power sources are more efficient, light weight, small and cost effective than the high power tubes.  Quasi-optical techniques are also capable of improving the dynamic range of mixers and low-noise amplifiers. The circuits can be realized in grid configurations using planar circuit topology which is compatible to future monolithic implementation for low cost production. In phase I, research activities will be focussed on developing these techniques and concepts.  A few prototype circuits will be fabricated and tested in order to verify the concepts.  Development, fabrication and production techniques for these high performance circuits will be addressed in Phase II.
title: High Frequency solid-state Devices

abstract: A study will be conducted to develop actively-cooled structural   concepts for high heat transfer engine inlet regions of scramjet   engines.  The program is directed toward the HyTech missile system   and employs laminated foil microchannel cooling technology.  The   program will consist of four basic tasks: (1) definition of design   requirements; (2) design trade studies to develop the optimum size,   weight, and performance characteristics of the cooled structure;   (3) fabrication and laboratory testing of an instrumented prototype   cooled model; and (4) planning for a follow-on test program to   validate the performance of the prototype design and the accuracy   of the analytical design methods.  The resultant cooled structure   can be used as an alternative, or back up, concept to the passive   structures under current development for the HyTech program, and   can also be utilized as a constant shape, instrumented model holder   for high heat flux testing of passive material panels.
title: Microchannel-Cooled Structure for Hypersonic Engine Inlets (Hypersonic Vehicle Technology)
Optimization and Testing of Rotor Optical Data Interface for Helicopters

abstract: This small business innovative research phase I project from Sagent Corporation addresses the need to develop and demonstrate high-performance nonlinear, adaptive, and hybrid systems cdontrol technology for precision multi-target, multi-platform fire-on-the-move applications including armor, air defense and aircraft system applications.  Reliance on incremental improvements in linear, fixed-point controllers as the means of implementing control of real-time systems has been a primary source of ever-increasing software costs associated with fielding new weapon systems.  Recent developments in adaptive control and robust multivariable control also fall short of the need for flexible integration of safety constraings and performance constraints for futrue combat systems.  Fuzzy logic and neural net controllers do not provide a means of integrating command and control logic with real-time control software.  This project will further develo9 the Multiple-Agent Hybrid Control Architecture (MAHCA) as a means to synchronize operation of the diverse system components being developed for future multi-platform, fire-on-the-move applications. This will result i the integration of previous results for single-agent precision stabilizatio and tracking control of a highly nonlinear plant with other results for multiple-agent modeling of the multi-platform engagement problem.
title: Advanced Nonlinear and Hybrid Systems Control Technology

abstract: This proposal is to examine the feasability of using biodegradable, injectable gels as drud delivery vehicle for a model analgesic drugf, Bupronophine, for the release and management of severe acute and chronic pain.  We propose to develop a controlled release biodegradable, injectable gel formulation for Bupronorphine Hydrochloride (water soluble salt) and Bupronorphine base (water insoluble) that can be injected subcutaneously.  three differnet molecular weight of the polymers and four different drug loadings will be used to formulate drug-loaded gels of varying compositions. Factors affecting in-vitro drug release rates from the gel formulations will be evaluated.  Two optimized formulations will be selected for an in vivo afficasy experinments.  The selected drug formulations are expected to provide analgesia for a prolonged period of time.  The therapeutic application of such novel technology would be of tremendous benefit to patients suffering from severe acute  and chronic pain.  Besides clinical benefits, the technology described in the proposal has tremendous commercial potential in a large number of areas.
title: Stable, Biodegradable Sustain-Release Analgesic System

abstract: Although laboratory research has indicated that measures of brain   electrical activity can be useful indices of a crewperson's mental   workload, this work has not yet been transitioned into operational   environments.  A major remaining obstacle in this regard is the   fact that current generation EEG sensors usually require manual   preparation of the skin surface prior to application and use of   messy liquid or gelatinous electrolytes.  This limitation makes   such technology impractical for routine use in operational   environments.  The aim of the proposed Phase I work is to evaluate   prototype designs for a Rapid Application Cutaneous Electrode   (RACE) System that would permit fast application of bioelectric   sensors on the scalp of subjects without significant preparation of   the recording sites.  This work will build on results from our   prior efforts to develop instant application electrodes and   holders.  The Phase II effort will involve development and testing   of a RACE based on the best Phase I design.
title: Rapid Application Cutaneous Electrode (RACE) System
PROPOSAL FOR AN INK-JET RAPID PROTOTYPING MACHINE

abstract: We propose to build an energy extractive Individual Portal (I-Port) to the virtual world enabling the user to traverse a large virtual workspace in a very small real space.  Using a commercial exercise treadmill, this device will improve virtual training, health maintenance and evaluation, and have a large market for education, recreation, and adversarial gaming.  A motion capture, energy extraction platform makes 3 important contributions to the use of Virtual Reality interface by: allowing large displacement movement in the virtual workspace, using energy extraction to induce fatigue and complicate decision making, increasing the user's immersion in the virtual world through force protection.  We minimize the floor space required by restricting the real work space to the treadmill surface.  This Phase I SBIR will investigate technologies to reduce system cost, improve reliability and safety, and build a prototype demonstration system.
title: A New Generation Virtual Reality Individual Portal

abstract: Many applications exist for structures, surfaces and materials whose shape, mechanical properties, or functional behavior can be altered in real-time to respond to changing conditions without explicit external commands.  Automated systems which interconnect, address, and control large numbers of distributed sensing and actuation elements (pressure sensors, shear sensors, microflaps, etc.) are key to the implementation of such Â¿smartÂ¿ structures.  Fiberoptic technology shows promise for this application since many devices can potentially be multiplexed along single fibers, and the fibers may be easily integrated with structures.SRC has a technology for interfacing such devices with fiberoptic communication lines.  The fiberoptic interface is fabricated using SRC's proprietary cylindrical micro-fabrication technology and is much smaller than existing optical modulators.  The technique involves a microfabricated piezoelectric actuator on the optical fiber.  The actuator is used to modulate the light in the fiber to transmit data.  When SRC matures this technology, distributed networks of microdevices, such as pressure sensors or strain sensors, could be interconnected and addressed.  With our technology, a single optical fiber could be used to interconnect many microdevices and communicate their data to a central receiver at high data rates for each interface node.
agency: Office of the Secretary of Defense
title: FIBEROPTIC INTERFACES (FOIs) FOR SENSOR NETWORKS

abstract: Pyrotechnic devices contain mixtures of metals, metal salts, oxidizers, and binders.  SASCO's proposed process is based upon extensive experience in metal recovery, production, mining, chemical, and reclamation fields. SASCO's system consists of opening the pyrotechnic device, removing the binder, the pyrophoric metals, the oxidizers, and recovering the metal salts. The outer casing of the device will be breached, and the binder will be dissolved.  Most binders are Viton material, which according to Naval Ordinance Systems Command Specifications #7682, is soluble in acetone. Other solvents can also be used to dissolve the binder and reclaim it as an elastomer.  Oxidizers such as sodium nitrate and potassium Perchlorate are soluble in organic liquids such as methanol.  Physical separation techniques will separate and recover individual magnesium and aluminum metals without alteration.  Copper, strontium, and other metal salts will be dissolved and recrystallized.  SASCO has experience in solvent extraction and ion exchange if such techniques are required.  SASCO will create a safe, environmentally acceptable, economically viable, and technically successful project by employing as few steps as possible to separate-components into pure forms.  Operations will be conducted at low temperatures under an inert gas or liquid blanket.
title: Reclamation/Reuse of Pyrotechnic Ingredients

abstract: Sat Con proposes to develop permanent magnet varia                    ble speed drives (PMVSDs) for  US Navy submarine auxiliary applications by integrating high density drive electronics  with innovative PM motor designs.  This will create a standardized set of rotating  power modules with common electrical and coolant interfaces.             As Navy power  distribution systems evolve to DC bus architecture, the power electronics-driven cost  disadvantage of PMVSDs will be reduced.  The reduction in start-up current surge and  higher efficiency of PMVSD operation will also reduce cost, while reduced motor start-  up current should decrease submarine power distribution system size and capacity  requirements.  In Phase I SatCon will study the cost and performance impact of introducing PMVSD  technology into submarine auxiliary systems, and will determine the applications likely  to benefit from its introduction.  These results will be analyzed to estimate impact  of this technology on a typical submarine, and on overall fleet operations.  SatCon  will generate a preliminary PMVSD design for a significant candidate submarine  application.   SatCon proposes an option to consider variable speed induction motor  drives for comparison.  These design data will be used to validate and update initial  predictions of cost and performance impact on submarine operation.         Based on the  expectation that PMVSD technology offers significant overall benefit, in Phase II  SatCon will generate detailed PMVSD designs for representative submarine applications,  identified as significant to fleet cost effectiveness during Phase I. In Phase III,  a prototype PMVSD will be fabricated   for submarine qualification.
title: Application of Permanent Magnet Variable Speed Drives to Auxiliary Applications in US Navy Submarines

abstract: SatCon proposes to develop a gearless high torque density permanent magnet machine for traction motor applications.  The combination of a large diameter air gap, high coercivity rare earth magnets, and a high ratio of magnet length to pole pitch permits torque densities in excess of 1600 ft-lbs./ft(3) without the added complexity and inefficiency of a gear reducer.  SatCon has developed and analyzed a conceptual design of a permanent magnet which is roughly 10 inches long by 23 inches i diameter.  Initial analyses indicate that it can achieve 300 kW over an operating speed of 400-3600 rpm, while maintaining an efficiency of better than 93% down to 400 rpm.  At 400 rpm and 300 kW the machine is producing 5280 ft-lbs. and, therefore, is achieving a torque density of 2200 ft-lbs./ft(3).  the high efficiency of the motor and the absence of a gearbox allows overall efficiency of the motor and electronics to exceed 90% over the entire speed range.  At speeds above 400 rpm the same power is achieved at even better efficiency, since the required torque falls off.  Since the maximum power capability remains constant at 300 kW over the speed range, the terminal voltage required for maximum power need not change with speed.  THis approach, known a field weakening, is commonly used with DC and induction motors.  The phase I will proceed through requirements definition, design tradeoffs, and detail design to arrive at a optimum design which would be built and tested in a phase II.  Emphasis will be given to efficiency, torque production and control, thermal management, control/commutation of phase currents, and drive inverter design and performance.
title: Gearless Permanent Magnet Motor for Vehicle Traction Applications

abstract: Magnetic bearings will dramatically improve performance of gas turbine engines by permitting high rotor speeds and combustion temperatures.  Lubrication systems are also eliminated, reducing weight and logistic support.  These huge potential benefits are essential to the Integrated High Performance Turbine Engine Technology Program (IHPTET).  SatCon Technology Corporation's magnetic bearings have been tested to 36,000 RPM under contract with the Army's Power Systems Division.  However, several key issues remain.  No magnetic bearing system (MBS) has auxiliary bearings and control software that allow touchdown and recovery at engine operating speeds of 50,000 RPM, or is built with high temperature materials that will withstand 1,100F.  In addition, actuators and power electronics must be designed for low losses and minimal power dissipation.  In Phase I, SatCon will perform the initial analyses necessary to design a MBS that can satisfy the JTAGG II and III operating environment.  This design will address the key remaining issues. An integral part of this design effort will be test and validation on an existing gas turbine test rig, upgraded to operate at the JTAGG II speed of 50,000 RPM in Phase II.  Phase III will entail combining SatCon's magnetic and auxiliary bearing configurations with a JTAGG II or III engine.
title: An Efficient, Robust Magnetic Bearing System for JTAGG II Operating Conditions

abstract: SatCon Technology Corporation proposes to develop the next generation power controller module aimed at the integrated control and power functions desired for the Power Electronics Building Block (PEBB) which has broad goverment and commercial interest.  Building on power hybrid technology advances made by SatCon during participation in Chrysler Corporation's "Patriot" Hybrid Electric Race Car Program, SatCon Proposes to reduce the integrated power controller package size by an order of magnitude by combining the power and control electronics into a single module.  SatCon's efforts on the "Patriot" Program resulted in packaging densities of 20 kW per  pound and 440 watts per cubic inch, which compare quite favorably to the prior stat-of-the-art which was approximately 1/4 of these levels.  The proposed approach further integrates and simplifies the power and control electronics design and results in a building block amenable to a wide variety of power levels.  Anticipated Military Benefits:  The development of compact, modular electronic power controller drive systems provides a broad enabling technology base for a variety of military applications including electric and hybrid tactical vehicles, more-electric aircraft, and shipboard integrated power systems.  Similar benefits for commercial applications within the automotive, machine tool, process and utility idustries offer the promise of the high volume production and reduced cost necessary to foster broad implementation.
title: Modular Power Controller for Electric Drives
A Novel Sensor & Diagnostic System for High Speed Composite Flywheels

abstract:
40816                                           November 13, 1996
SatCon Technology Corporation

While cost-effective, high performance electric motors are crucial to the success of any electric or hybrid-electric vehicle program, their manufacturability is the primary impediment to their development.  This project will decrease manufacturing costs by developing new fabrication techniques for rotor assemblies and thinly laminated stator stacks.  The rotor assembly concept involves using an innovative bonding technique to assemble a net-shape copper squirrel cage to a net-shape magnetic core.  The laminated stack concept involves using an advanced spray-forming process to fabricate cores of arbitrarily thin laminations in a one-step process.  Phase I will demonstrate the feasibility of using these techniques to make electric motors with a performance-to-cost ratio that will make them economically viable, thus bringing electric automobiles another step closer to reality.

Anticipated Results/Potential Commercial Applications as described by the awardee:  Most applications that use rotating machinery or require high power-to-weight ratios can enjoy an efficiency improvement through higher rotational speeds.  Electric vehicles and next-generation high-speed turbo machines (e.g., HVAC compressors) are the nearest-term and largest market applications for cost-effective, high-performance electric motors.
title: Innovative Bonding and Spray-Forming Techniques for Cost-Effectively Producing High Performance Induction Motors

abstract: This advanced development program is devoted to adapting SATIMO's proprietary Microwave Camera design and the associated proprietary microwave imaging codes based on Augumented Diffraction Tomography (ADT) and the Volumetric Electric Field Integral Equation (VEFIE) to provide efficient 3-D imaging of water movement along perferred flow channels during snowmelt.  The customized Microwave Camera will utilize an array of electrically-small probes to provide the requisite Nyquist-sampled measurements of the scattered microwave signals at sampling rtes of 1000 points per second or higher; the advanced ADT code will provide quasi-real time qualitative 3-D microwave images of water channels having diameters of 0.5 cm to 10.0 cm or larger in the 0.5 m^3 to 1.0 m^3 volume under test, and the advanced VEFIE code will provide efficient quantitative 3-D images "off-line".  Model simulations will be performed 1) to demonstrate the basic operating principals of the 3-D imaging system consisting of the Microwave Camera and the ADT and VEFIE imaging codes and 2) to determine critical design parameters and expected performance envelopes for the Phase II prototype system.  One of SATIMO's existing Microwave Cameras will be used to conduct preliminary imaging sensitivity experiments for known water channels in a simulated porous medium in order to expedite the preliminary design process for the customized camera.
title: Advanced Microwave Camera for 3-D Imaging of Water Channels in a Porous Medium
Advanced MST Automated Electromagnetic Field Probe for Anechoic Chamber Testing

abstract: This Phase I proposal provides an innovative concept for an Eye Safe-Laser Seeker and Designator (ES-LSD) suitable for implementation to a high G launched projectile.  The concept proposed operates equally for spinning or non-spinning projectiles.  The uniqueness of this concept is vested to the type of detector mechanism selected, and specifically the mounting technique and the geometry of the detector proper.  No moving parts are envisioned for the detector mechanisms; thus, the concept is valuable in regard to the required large acceleration effected to the projectile at the time of launch. The receiver/seeker/detector mechanism will be optimized to operate with an Erbium laser transmitter, in order that the system qualifies as "eye-safe." The work described in this proposal will utilize the advantages of the simplicity of Er:Glass and mitigate the disadvantages with innovative technologies.  The innovative technologies developed under this effort will include the optimization of pumping technology, of Q-switch technology, of Er:Glass dopant concentration, and the design of a ruggedized laser transmitter for ranging a designation. Schwartz Electro-Optics, Inc. (SEO) will develop the seeker for the ES-LSD, while Kiger, Inc. will develop the eye-safe laser using Er:Glass material. The SEO and Kiger team will also work on testing the ES-LSD system.
title: Eye Safe- Laser Seeker and Designator (ES-LSD)

abstract: This proposal is part of a TRP whose aim is the development and commercialization of a generic 2 micrometers coherent lidar transceiver with a variety of airborne wind sensing applications in both commercial and military avionics.  These include: flight-level-optimization, clear-air turbulence detection, wind shear detection and avoidance, and wake-vortex detection.  For specifiec military use, applications include: gunship wind sensing and wind mapping for precision air and bomb drop missions.  A central feature of the lidar system is the laser transmitter, whose preliminary specifications are >10 mJ pulse energies, pulse repetition rate of 200 Hz , and a pulse duration of greater than 400 ns.  TEM00-singel frequency operation is a prerequisite, and the system must operate in an ambient temperature of up to 55 degrees C with a maximum power budget of 500W.  The compact, rugged transceiver must be air-cooled to simplify installation and maximize lifetime.  This SBIR program proposes to demonstrate the above laser performance on a breadboarded system, basing its design on an existing Tm,Ho:YLF laser.  We intend to investigate cooling schema capable of maintaining the defined performance in an airborne environment and within the defined power budget.  The results of this embeded SBIR program will provide invaluable input to the associated TRP.  Anticipated Military Benefits:  A generic coherent airborne lidar system will porovide wind sensing data for closed loop correction of gunship targeting, allowing incresed stand-off.  Wind mapping of air-space under aircraft will enhance precison air and bomb drop missions.  Use of this technology in commercial (and military) avionics would provide fuel savings (via flight level optimization) and increased passenger safety (via clear-air-turbulence, wind shear and wake vortex detection).
title: Efficiency and Performance Enhancement of Tm, Ho: YLF Lidar

agency: Department of Health and Human Services
title: SOLID STATE LASER FOR THROMBOLYSIS
Single-Frequency Tunable IR Laser Development

abstract: The main objective of this proposal is to design and develop an all-solid-state, high repetition rate laser source, tunable throughout the 1.5 to 3.5 um wavelength range. The proposed source will have a peak power greater than 1 kW at multi-kHz repetition rate. It will be based upon an optical parametric oscillator (OPO), and provides the wide tuning range by utilizing a pump source which is also widely tunable - a diode-pumped Cr:LiSAF laser. This unique device utilizes an OPO with a low threshold that allows use of diode-pumped laser. Specific aims of the Phase I effort include an investigation of a range of newly available efficient Arsenate nonlinear optical materials, KTA, CTA and RTA that have transmission out to 5 um. Experiments will be performed using a high pulse energy tunable pump laser, to demonstrate OPO oscillation in these crystals, and to establish their threshold pump energy requirement.  We will also demonstrate the broad tunability achieved by using a tunable pump source.  Finally, the design of phase II high pulse energy (2-3mJ), tunable (780-1000nm) Cr:LiSAF pump laser will be carried out.  In phase II the miniature mid-IR OPO pumped by the diode-pumped tunable laser will be fabricated and tested.
title: Mid-Infrared OPO Pumped by a Tunable Diode Pumped Solid State Laser

abstract: A feasibility and optimization investigation is proposed for electromagnetic immunity and emission testing over the frequency regime of 10 KHz to 18 GHz. The proposed facility combines the cost-effective performance features of a TEM cell and a reverberation chamber.  The feasibility investigation emphasizes the reduction of test result uncertainty in transition region between the upper limit of a TEM cell and the lower limit of a reverberation chamber.  The investigation will include three design options and combines numerical modeling techniques, and analyses of statistical distribution functions for the electromagnetic environment.  The feasibility of achieving an acceptable uncertainty in the electromagnetic environment in the transition region of a hybrid TEM/RC test facility will be evaluated in the Phase I effort.
title: Investigation of a Hybrid Electromagnetics Test Facility

abstract: In the present domestic and world political climate, U.S. military forces are faced with situations requiring less-than-lethal response options.  Low-energy lasers can be effective, non-lethal weapons for a variety of military missions and law enforcement applications.  Through the effects of illumination, glare, flashblinding and psychological impact, lasers can create surrender, hesitation, delay, distractions, temporary visual impairment, and reductions in combat and functional effectiveness. Furthermore, these effects can be created at eye-safe exposure levels below the maximum allowed by international safety standards.  SEA proposed the exploratory development of four laser concepts that provide the individual soldier or law enforcement officer with a range of non-lethal response options employing existing hardware and weapon systems.  These are a flashlight laser, a baton laser, a shotgun shell laser, and a grenade shell laser.  During Phase I, SEA will evaluate these four concepts relative to Army mission requirements.  Based on this evaluation, on of the concepts will be selected for Phase I development and tested as a demonstrator prototype.  If the project is selected for a Phase II SBIr, SEA will take one or more of the four concepts through advanced development and provide the Army with several fieldable prototypes for testing in operational situations.
title: Eye-Safe Lasers as a Non-Lethal Option for the Individual Soldier

abstract: The Defense Nuclear Agency hase undertaken several related programs to develop new technologies for countering the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, including weapons which disperse dry spore biological agents.  These initiatives require an increased understanding of the response o fthese agents and their surrogates to the environments generated by various weapons, including penetrating weapons with high exposive fills and weapons containging agent neutralization contaminants.  recent experiments suggest that these environments can cause substantial damage to spores but do not clarify the damage mechanisms.  Thsi proposal addresses (1) the development of models for the separate effects of thermal and mechanical loadings on spores, (2) the initial development of models with expanded capabilities, including the effects of combined thermal, mechanical, and chemical attacks, and (3) the design of experiments to fill gaps in the current data base on these effects.  The expanded odels will be developed and the experimental program will be conducted during Phase II.
title: Response of Dry Spore Biological Agets and Surrogates to Weapons Environment

abstract: SESI proposes the development of a novel flow cytometer to detect biological warfare agents in large multiplex of up to 300 agents.  Our proposed cytometer combines new phosphorescence technology in conjunction with a state-of-the-art flow cytometer configuration to achieve simultaneous 300-agent multiplexing without further complication of the cytometer design.  Up to 60 agents could be simultaneously detected in a flow cytometer equipped with only an upconversion phosphor channel and forward scattering.  An innovative feature of our channel as a baseline operation, as well as phosphor channel performance using the fundamental laser wavelength.  In addition, the flow cytometer configuration will implement an electric cell volume measurement capability for accurate sizing of individual cells.  The proposed cytometer optically, and electrically, probes individual cells at rates of up to 1000 cells per second.  This flow speed of the cytometer allows continuous point sampling and monitoring.  Second generation advances in miniaturization, (which will speed up assay kinetics and reduce the sample volumes required to achieve detection) may permit use of this system on mobile platforms, such as the UAV.
title: Development of Novel Flow Cytometer for Biological Warfare Agent Detection
A HIGH SPECTRAL PURITY REGENERATIVE LIFSAF AMPLIFIER FOR WATER VAPOR LIDAR

abstract: Science Quest, Incorporated (SQI) proposes to develop an innovative Trauma Care Decision System which will considerably enhance efficiency of pre-hospital trauma care.  The system will be capable of accepting multiple sensors data, and provide fast decision, identify high risk patients, estimate patients' survival time and identify the most efficient treatment.  The decision algorithms will be based on the use of neural assemblies and bi-radial bases neural networks.  In SQI methodology, identification of high risk patients and predication of their survival time is reduced to prediction of the values of the danger functions, which characterize the patients' conditions and their survival time. Developed software will be integrated in hand-held personal computer and adapted for multiple medical sensors logging.  The decision making algorithm will be capable to accept data from pH tissue analysis, oxygen tissue analysis, cardiac analysis, and other sensors and will be capable to work with different combinations of input parameters without redesigning the algorithm and retraining the neural network.  The set of sensors providing input data for decision making algorithm will be integrated in Pre-Hospital Trauma Care Management Networks.
title: Fast Neural Networks Decision Algorithm for Pre-Hospital Trauma Care

abstract: Radiation curing using Ultraviolet (UV) Light and Electron Beams (EB) offer advantages for a variety of aircraft structural and non-structural applications.  Radiation curing of fiber-reinforced polymer composites, paints, adhesives and sealants can offer processing and cost advantages over conventional materials.  Radiation curable paints are solvent-free, an environmental, health and safety and advantage and cure quickly (< 1 minute).  Recent advances in UV and EB curing systems and in radiation-curable chemistry formulations have made it possible to achieve weatherable UV and EB curable paints for aircraft.  Advances in UV and EB curing systems include portable, high intensity sources with low capital costs.  Chemistry advances include recently available oligomers, photoinitiators, synergists and UV stabilizers.  Science Research Laboratory (SRL) has developed a new generation of electron beam acccelerators and pulsed UV systems for curing of polymer matrix composites and radiation curable coatings.  Electron accelerators include portable electron guns for curing of paints and coatings and high energy accelerators for curing of thick-section composites.  The portable electron guns use commercially available power supplies to reduce selling costs to under $100,000.  High energy accelerators and pulsed UV systems utilize all solid-state high repetition rate pulsed power drivers which reduce the capital cost while increasing system reliability.  A program is proposed to develop a radiation-curable aircraft painting system, including optimized materials and processing equipment.  Phase I inculdes material optimization and system design.  A portable curing system based on the Phase I design will be delivered during Phase II.  Anticipated Military Benefits:  A radiation-curable painting system based on SRL technology has both military and commercial applications.  In the commercial sector, such a system will allow environmentally safe, cost-effective painting of automotive frames and components.
title: Advanced Ultraviolet and Electron Beam Curable Systems for Aircraft Applications

abstract:
40870                                           November 13, 1996
Science Research Laboratory, Inc.

Several verification technologies for nuclear nonproliferation treaties use techniques that are based upon Prompt Neutron Activation (PNA) and neutron inelastic scattering.  However, the use of neutrons is severely limited by the lack of an adequate electronic source.  This project will develop a compact neutron generator to be used in devices for nuclear non-proliferation treaty verification.  In Phase I,  a neutron generator consisting of a compact (1.1 m length, 0.65 m dia.), lightweight (120 kgm) and low power (kW) accelerator (100 Â¿A beam of D+ ions at 600 keV) and a 9Be target will be brought to final engineering design. This generator will produce 2 x 109 n/s (> 2 x 1010 n/s with increased target cooling) with a lifetime of >2000 hrs MTBF.  Phase I will also test a novel tritiated titanium target design that is expected to increase tritium target lifetime tenfold for applications requiring higher neutron yields.  In Phase II, the neutron generator will be fabricated and evaluated in the field.

Anticipated Results/Potential Commercial Applications as described by the awardee:  The applications of a low cost, long lived, compact neutron source in industry and medicine are widespread, ranging from quality control in advanced manufacturing systems to explosives and contraband detection.
title: A Compact Neutron Generator
All-Solid-State Drivers for High Power Excimer Lasers Used in Projection Gas Immersion Laser Doping
